Understanding the Functional Behaviour Assessment Process

AssessmentFunctional AnalysisEvidence-Based

What is Functional Behaviour Assessment?

Functional Behaviour Assessment (FBA) is a systematic process for understanding why behaviours occur. It forms the foundation of effective behaviour support by identifying the purpose or function that behaviours serve for the individual.

Why is FBA Important?

Without understanding why a behaviour occurs, support strategies may be ineffective or even counterproductive. FBA helps ensure that interventions address the root causes rather than just the surface behaviours. This evidence-based approach:

  • Identifies the purpose or function of behaviours
  • Reveals patterns and triggers
  • Guides effective intervention strategies
  • Reduces the use of ineffective or harmful approaches

The FBA Process: Step by Step

1. Information Gathering

This involves collecting information from various sources:

  • Interviews with the participant, family members, and support workers
  • Review of existing documentation (NDIS plans, reports, incident records)
  • Analysis of previous support strategies and their effectiveness
  • Understanding the individual's preferences, strengths, and goals

2. Direct Observation

Structured observations are conducted in relevant environments:

  • Systematic data collection across different settings
  • Recording of antecedents (what happens before), behaviours, and consequences
  • Identification of patterns in behaviour occurrence
  • Understanding environmental factors that influence behaviour

3. Data Analysis

The collected information is analyzed to identify:

  • When and where behaviours are most likely to occur
  • What triggers or sets off the behaviours
  • What maintains or reinforces the behaviours
  • What function the behaviours serve for the individual

4. Hypothesis Development

Based on the analysis, hypotheses are developed about:

  • Why behaviors occur (their function)
  • What maintains them
  • What environmental factors contribute
  • What intervention strategies are likely to be effective

5. Report and Recommendations

A comprehensive report is prepared with:

  • Detailed findings from the assessment process
  • Clear hypotheses about behaviour function
  • Evidence-based recommendations for support strategies
  • Measurable goals and outcome indicators

Timeline and Expectations

The FBA process typically takes 2-4 weeks, depending on the complexity of the situation and availability of stakeholders. The assessment is collaborative and requires input from all relevant parties to be effective.

Collaboration is Key

Successful FBA requires active participation from everyone involved in the person's life. This includes the individual (where possible), family members, support workers, and other relevant professionals. The more comprehensive the information gathering, the more effective the resulting support strategies will be.

From Assessment to Action

The FBA findings directly inform the development of the Behaviour Support Plan, ensuring that all strategies are based on a thorough understanding of the individual's needs and the factors influencing their behaviour. This evidence-based approach provides the best foundation for positive outcomes.
